name: Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS)
summary: A non-invasive brain stimulation technique that applies weak electrical currents to modulate neuronal excitability and improve symptoms in depression, anxiety, and other conditions.
description: Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) is a form of non-invasive neuromodulation that uses constant, low-amplitude electrical currents delivered via scalp electrodes to alter cortical excitability. Unlike TMS, it does not induce action potentials but instead modulates neuronal firing thresholds. It has been investigated for depression, anxiety, chronic pain, and cognitive enhancement. tDCS is portable, relatively inexpensive, and well tolerated, though its clinical efficacy varies by condition and stimulation protocol.

metadata.treatment_duration: Typically 5–20 sessions over 2–4 weeks, sometimes with maintenance

contraindications: Implanted medical devices (e.g., pacemakers, deep brain stimulators)
Open scalp wounds or lesions at electrode sites
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe with mild transient side effects such as tingling, itching, or mild headache. Rare risk of skin irritation or burns with improper electrode placement.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate—well-studied in depression and motor rehabilitation, mixed results across other conditions.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Dozens of RCTs support efficacy in depression and stroke recovery; evidence for other uses is less consistent.

sections.text: tDCS delivers a constant, low-intensity current (typically 1–2 mA) through electrodes placed on the scalp. Anodal stimulation generally increases cortical excitability, while cathodal stimulation decreases it. By modulating neuronal firing thresholds, tDCS can influence brain plasticity and functional connectivity.

sections.preparation: Electrodes placed over target cortical areas with saline-soaked sponges or conductive gel.
procedure: Current set to 1–2 mA, ramped up gradually.
Sessions repeated daily or several times weekly.
sections.frequency: 5–20 sessions across 2–4 weeks; booster sessions as needed.
sections.duration: Acute course often followed by maintenance depending on response.

long_term: Sustained symptom reduction when combined with psychotherapy or rehabilitation

ideal_candidates: Patients with depression not fully responsive to medication

studies: RCTs show moderate antidepressant efficacy, especially when combined with SSRIs or psychotherapy.
Stroke rehabilitation studies demonstrate motor recovery benefits.
Evidence for cognitive enhancement and anxiety reduction is mixed.
sections.limitations: Small effect sizes, variability in protocols, lack of standardized dosing parameters.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Several hundred to a few thousand dollars depending on course length.
sections.insurance_coverage: Not typically covered in most regions.
sections.cost_effectiveness: Low cost compared to other neuromodulation techniques; effectiveness depends on condition and protocol.

sections.pediatric: Experimental in ADHD and learning disorders; not standard of care.
sections.elderly: Generally safe, though skin fragility may increase irritation risk.
sections.pregnancy: Insufficient evidence for safety; generally avoided.
sections.comorbidities: Careful screening for epilepsy and implanted devices is required.

items: Portable tDCS devices are being developed for home use but are not yet widely approved.
Best outcomes seen when combined with behavioral or rehabilitative interventions.
Safety profile is favorable compared to more invasive neuromodulation.
